individual.title.title.segment: LOLA F. MARTIN and MALCOLM D.S. MARTIN, et al., Plaintiffs,
MIDWEST EXPRESS HOLDINGS, INC., et al., Defendants.

head.headtext: ORDER DENYING MOTION TO CERTIFY FOR IMMEDIATE APPEAL AND STAY [225]

content.judge.judge.line: DOLLY M. GEE United States District Judge

para.paratext: This matter is before the court on the motion by third-party plaintiffs Midwest Express Holdings, Inc., Midwest Airlines, Inc., and Astral Aviation, Inc. dba Skyway Airlines, Inc. (collectively, “Skyway”) to certify this court's December 30, 2009 Order Re: Motion for Partial Summary Judgment (“Order”) (Doc. # 214) for immediate appeal pursuant to 28 U.S.C. §1292(b), and to stay all trial proceedings (“Certification Motion”) (Doc. #225). The Court deems this matter appropriate for decision without oral argument. Fed. R. Civ. P. 78(b); C.D. Cal. L.R. 7-15.

In May 2005, Skyway, as defendants in the underlying personal injury action, settled with plaintiffs in the underlying action for the sum of $8 million for injuries incurred by plaintiffs. Skyway's third-party complaint for indemnity against Fairchild Dornier Corporation, Fairchild Dornier GmbH, Fairchild Dornier Luftfahrt Beteiligungs GmbH, and Dr. Eberhard Braun (collectively, “Fairchild”) remains to be litigated.

Thereafter, the Fairchild third-party defendants moved for partial summary judgment on the third-party complaint asserting that they are not liable to indemnify Skyway for that portion of Skyway's settlement sum attributable to non-economic damages. On December 30, 2009, Hon. Gary A. Feess issued the Order holding that California law applied and that thereunder, pursuant to Proposition 51, California Civil Code § 1431.2, “the liability of each defendant for non-economic damages shall be several only and shall not be joint.” Order, at 4, quoting Section 1431.2 (emphasis in original). Skyway now seeks certification of that interlocutory order for immediate appeal.
Section 1292(b) of the United States Code sets forth the standard governing the certification of interlocutory appeals:

When a district judge, in making in a civil action an order not otherwise appealable under this section, shall be of the opinion that such order involves a controlling question of law as to which there is substantial ground for difference of opinion and that an immediate appeal from the order may materially advance the ultimate termination of the litigation, he shall so state in writing in such order. The Court of Appeals ․ may thereupon, in its discretion, permit an appeal to be taken from such order. ․”
28 U.S.C. §1292(b); see also Ovando v. City of Los Angeles, 92 F. Supp. 2d 1011, 1025 (C.D. Cal. 2000).

Skyway contends that the Order involves a controlling question of law whose resolution will determine “whether Skyway is entitled to pursue indemnity for both economic and non-economic damages, or whether it is entitled to pursue indemnity for economic damages only.” (Memo. in Supp of Certification Motion, at 6; emphasis in original.) [Doc. # 226.]
The Ninth Circuit has grappled with the meaning of the words “controlling question of law”:

While Congress did not specifically define what it meant by “controlling,” the legislative history of 1292(b) indicates that this section was to be used only in exceptional situations in which allowing an interlocutory appeal would avoid protracted and expensive litigation.
[A]ll that must be shown in order for a question to be “controlling” is that resolution of the issue on appeal could materially affect the outcome of litigation in the district court.
In re Cement Antitrust Litigation (MDL NO. 296), 673 F.2d 1020, 1026 (9th Cir. 1981) (citations omitted).

Although the Order is, in a sense, “controlling” as to the issue of whether Skyway may pursue indemnity for non-economic damages, any order, by definition, is controlling as to that which is the subject of the order. What is a more important consideration here is that immediate resolution of the issue on appeal would have minimal impact on the pending litigation or its outcome. Even without an interlocutory appeal, the jury will be instructed to specify which portion of the damages is for economic damages and which portion is for non-economic damages. An immediate appeal would not “avoid protracted and expensive litigation,” and even if the Order is ultimately overturned on appeal, that would not necessitate retrial. Any potential error in the computation of damages in favor of Skyway could be remedied simply by a mathematical reapportionment of the non-economic damages.

headtext.bold: B. SUBSTANTIAL GROUND FOR DIFFERENCE OF OPINION

para.paratext: Skyway contends that a substantial ground for difference of opinion exists as to whether application of California law would require the conclusion that Section 1431.2 precludes Skyway from recovering for non-economic damages under its indemnity claim here. Skywest points out that, at the time of its settlement with plaintiff, it was not clear which state's laws would apply and it was reasonable to believe that California law might not apply.
Skyway's position is encapsulated in one of the Ninth Circuit's unpublished opinions, In re Dow Corning Corporation, 220 Fed.Appx. 457, 458 (2007):

Under California law, HRC is entitled to equitable indemnity if it had “a reasonable belief” that settlement was necessary, “even though it develops that [it] in fact had no interest to protect.” HRC need not prove its own liability, but indemnity is unavailable if HRC “faced neither actual, potential nor reasonably apparent liability.”
(Citations omitted; alterations in original.)

Skyway contends that because it was reasonable to believe at the time of the settlement that California law might not apply, it was not a “volunteer” in settling the non-economic damages claim and, therefore, should not be barred from seeking indemnity. On this basis, Skyway contends that there is substantial ground for difference of opinion. The Court notes, however, that as early as February 28, 2005, three months before court approval of the settlement, Skyway asserted that California law and Proposition 51 applied herein.1 As such, there are indicators that Skyway foresaw the applicability of California law.
On February 28, 2005, Skyway filed its Answer to the Fairchild cross-claim [Doc. #63] in which the Seventh Affirmative Defense is based on “Allocation of Liability – Proposition 51.”
Moreover, as this Court stated in its February 18, 2010 order:

The briefs filed herein make it clear that all parties are in agreement that (1) California law applies unless a party invokes the law of another state, (2) no party in this action has invoked the law of another state, and (3) the Skyway third-party plaintiffs and the Fairchild third-party defendants assert that California law applies.
Order Resetting Hearing on Motion for Interlocutory Appeal, p. 2, filed 2/18/2010. [Doc. # 239.]

Because it has been all parties' position that California law applies and no party has intended to invoke the law of another state, this Court cannot conclude that there is a substantial ground for difference of opinion justifying an immediate appeal.2

The Court notes that in the Order, there is an error in the analysis used to determine whether California law applies. The Order erroneously asserts that, under Erie Railroad Co. V. Tompkins, 304 U.S. 64, 58 S. Ct. 817, 82 L. Ed. 1188 (1938), California substantive law applies because this is a diversity jurisdiction case. The Erie doctrine, however, merely stands for the proposition that, in a diversity jurisdiction case such as this, it is state substantive law, rather than federal law, that applies. The Erie doctrine does not resolve the issue of which state's law applies. The resolution of the latter issue requires the application of the forum state's conflict of law rules. Patton v. Cox, 276 F.3d 493, 495 (9th Cir. 2002); Klaxon Co. V. Stentor Electric Mfg. Co., 313 U.S. 487, 496 (1941). The Court was correct, however, in its ultimate conclusion that California law applies.

headtext.bold: C. MATERIAL ADVANCEMENT OF THE ULTIMATE TERMINATION OF THE LITIGATION

para.paratext: Skyway contends that this prong is met because an immediate appeal would significantly reduce the likelihood of a retrial. As mentioned above, however, the Court does not find that there is any likelihood of a retrial. The jury can be instructed to specify the amount of and differentiate between economic damages and non-economic damages. As such, even if the Order is ultimately overturned on appeal, a retrial would not be necessary.3

Skyway contends that “under Fairchild's argument, the jury will not consider non-economic damages, and, accordingly, will not be asked to determine said damages. For purposes of this indemnity claim, however, the sum total of all damages, consisting of both economic and non-economic damages, is already set and circumscribed by the settlement amount. It will be for the jury to decide which portion thereof is attributable to economic damages and which portion is attributable to non-economic damages.

Based on the foregoing, it is this Court's conclusion that Skyway has failed to establish that the Order “involves a controlling question of law as to which there is substantial ground for difference of opinion and that an immediate appeal from the order may materially advance the ultimate termination of the litigation.” 28 U.S.C. § 1292(b).
Accordingly, Skyway's motion to certify this Court's December 30, 2009 Order Re: Motion for Partial Summary Judgment for immediate appeal and to stay all trial proceedings is DENIED.
IT IS SO ORDERED.
Dated: March 31, 2010
